climbs.name: Steve's Face
climbs.fa: Tim Campbell, Mike Russo, Serra Barron (FFA), Cory Lindskov

content.description: If Steve's Arete is the impeccable jaw line to this beautiful head of stone on Mt Lemmon, then you're in luck because now you can climb the face!While it might look like a shoddy squeeze-job to the critics, those who decide to rope in and give it a short whirl will undoubtedly be pleasantly surprised.  This short but stout line ascends the independent line up the left side of the east face of the pinnacle, requiring climbers to commit to jugs, slopers, and a series of familiar and positional Lemmon crimps to reach the anchors. While you may be tempted by your old comforts of the arete, be warned; your craving for familiar security will only lead you astray. Steve's Face needs love too. Go kiss it.
content.protection: 5 bolts with two various starts. Either do the typical ledge traverse to start or do the direct (Steve's Neck) start into the route. This can be done "run out" or protected with an optional cam/nut. Finish on the anchors of Steve's Arete or Green Ripper (FA done on Green Ripper).
content.location: East face of the Hunchback on the obvious line straight up the face to the left of Green Ripper

content.description: An outstanding overhanging arete.  Really positive holds and some great crimps as you get towards the top.  Beware of the pump factor, and don't fear the height of the first bolt.  It's on the cover of the Rock Climbing Arizona book.  Great photo ops.
content.protection:
4 bolts to chain anchors, quickdraws only.

 Bolts and top-anchors updated by CASA in 2017.

content.description: The route starts on a steep face with a bolt about 7 feet up that you can clip from the ground.  A long, tricky, technical crux section lies between the second and third bolts so be sure your belayer is paying attention as it is possible (though unlikely) that you could deck if you fall with enough slack.  Just above the third bolt is a short low-angle section followed by 25 feet of overhanging rock that goes at about 10a.  The climb is a fun one but be prepared to leave with sore fingertips.
content.location: Directly left of Danglefoot Dihedral and two routes left of Steve's Arete.  Look for a bolt that you can reach from the ground (I'm 5'10" and could just barely reach it).

content.description: This route is on the NW corner of the rock.  Once you're @ the top, use the chains on the back-left.  Good: Great view of Tucson.  Bad: You'll be in full-view of the gawking tourists at Windy Point..."Duh, how'd they get the rope up thur?"
content.protection: Passive pro <1" should do the trick.

content.description: Green Ripper is to the right of Steve's Arete as you look down towards the Highway.  It is also easily identified by the four ring bolts.  The route starts off of the the ledge.  The first bolt is easily clipped from there.  This climb packs a lot of climbing into 35 feet.  Two of the local guides give it only one star.  Climb it and see for yourself.  The climbing is powerful and fun.
content.protection: Four 3.75" stainless bolts to chain anchors.

content.description: On the first ascent Joe led this route with only one bolt placed.  Soon after he added the top bolt to make the route safer for the rest of us.  It is still runout to the first bolt, and most people begin this by climbing the direct start to Steve's Arete.
content.protection: 2 bolts.  Plus more if you begin with Steve's Arete Direct.
content.location: This is the next route left of Steve's Arete.  Note that there is a direct start to Steve's Arete, which offers a better protected way to begin this route.  The original line was left of this, however.

content.description: Hunchback Pinnacle is a prominent, freestanding formation just below Windy Point. Steve's Arete, which is on the cover of Rock Climbing Arizona by Stewart Green, is the highlight as it climbs the beautiful and exposed downhill side of the pinnacle.
